data: A s this year comes to a close, we are showcasing some of our favorite news stories, videos and slideshows of the year. This sampling illustrates four attributes (among many!) that we think make Amherst uniquely Amherst: our location, our community, our academics and our ideals. Enjoy. And Happy New Year! Seeing the Campus for the Trees by Katherine Duke After the College earned a special recognition from the Arbor Day Foundation, we took a closer look at some of our campus’s older residents . Falling In Love With Fall: A Brief, Seasonal Tour by Maria Stenzel At the peak of the fall season, the Mt. Holyoke Range provides a spectacular backdrop for the Amherst College community. Check out some of our favorite fall views . Your Guide to Study Spots at Amherst by Lindsey Huang ’26 A focus on places where you can… focus Between 2 Mammoths with Maida Ives by Marcus DeMaio Video: President Michael Elliott in conversation with Maida Ives, manager of farm education and operations , at the College’s own Book & Plow farm to discuss all aspects of her work. 3 Questions for Fred Venne on the Beneski Museum by Ben Clark-Eden ’25 The long-serving museum educator at the College’s science museum offered his own collection of experiences . Why I Love the Multicultural Student Union by Anna Hogarth ’23 Anna Hogarth ’23 wrote about walking into her first Multicultural Student Union meeting at Amherst last fall, and experiencing something she had never fully felt before: complete inclusion . “Working on Commencement Is the Best Feeling Ever” by Emily Gold Boutilier Leading up to the academic year’s biggest event, we interviewed six of the many staff members who work behind the scenes to ensure that Commencement is the celebration it is. Office Hours with Professor Frank Leon Roberts by Maria Stenzel and Jesse Gwilliam An enthusiastic member of the College’s English department tweets and talks about his approach to office hours. Between 2 Mammoths with Jacquelyn Cabarrubia ’25 by Marcus DeMaio Video: President Elliott sat down with Cabarrubia to talk about the Native Indigenous Students Association, which provides community-building space for Indigenous students on campus. A Snapshot of Amherst’s Newest Students by Caroline Hanna Some data points about the class of 2027 and fall transfer students–and a calendar reminder. Behind the Scenes: Senior Thesis Projects by Jesse Gwilliam We captured some photos of five students from the Class of 2023 who spent January rehearsing, practicing and studying for their most important final projects. When a Course Turns Into a Book by Caroline Hanna Published this fall, Being Human in STEM provides readers with a roadmap for creating their own version of the popular Amherst course of the same name. Between 2 Mammoths with Martha Umphrey by Marcus DeMaio Video: President Elliott and Professor Umphrey discussed the law and politics of free speech —and ways to engage students in free speech with curiosity and a sense of play, rather than fear. Meet Our Newest Faculty Amherst welcomed 31 new faculty members this academic year, spanning 24 departments and programs and holding degrees from institutions in at least 13 different countries. Data with Destiny by Katharine Whittemore A statistics class unearthed the data—and the stories —behind the history of the city of Holyoke, Mass. “We’ll Do Everything in the Bounds of the Law” by Caroline Hanna At a campus event in March, the subject was the future of race-conscious admissions and the Supreme Court . Massachusetts’ Governor on Democracy by Katharine Whittemore Gov. Maura Healy and President Elliott spoke about the challenges to democracy in our era–and how to serve the greater good . “No Person Is Too Small to Have a Larger Meaning” by Caroline Hanna At Commencement, President Elliott encouraged graduates to work together to protect rights and freedoms everywhere. Between 2 Mammoths with Elizabeth Aries by Marcus DeMaio Video: President Elliott and Professor Aries discussed her research and her book that looks into the impact of student body diversity during their college years and then 12 years later. Careering Through D.C. by Maria Stenzel and Katharine Whittemore A career trek in March introduced 12 students, bent on careers in government and nonprofits , to alumni who have found meaningful jobs in these sectors.
